DOC.HEAD: Israeli Troops Kill 2 Palestinians
Eds: LEADS with 4 grafs to UPDATE wounded. Pick up 4th pvs, `Also Thursday...'
DOC.TEXT: Israeli troops shot and killed two Palestinians on Thursday after soldiers were stoned as they tried to arrest uprising activists in a West Bank village, the army said. Five other Palestinians, two of them women, suffered gunshot wounds in the incident, Arab reports said. In the occupied Gaza Strip, 21 Palestinians were shot and wounded in scattered stone-throwing clashes with Israeli troops, Arab reports said. The military confirmed seven wounded in Gaza and five in the West Bank. Also Thursday, more than 150 Palestinian university administrators and professors launched a campaign to demand Israel to reopen colleges and universities closed by the army almost since the start of the Palestinian uprising. At an organizational meeting, the group said that the closures in the West Bank and Gaza since January 1988 were depriving 42,000 Palestinians of an education and seriously damaging the finances of the institutions. ``We are being banned from a basic right, access to schools and universities,'' Adib Khatib, a vice president at An-Najah University in Nablus, told the meeting in Jerusalem. ``This collective punishment must be brought to an end.'' The deaths occurred in Beit Furik, a village of about 5,000 people near Nablus. The army said soldiers raiding the village were attacked with stones and concrete blocks and that one officer was lightly wounded in the face. ``The soldiers shot a number of plastic bullets at the stone and block throwers,'' the army said. ``Later it was reported that two were killed.'' The victims, Ayesh Wajeeh Khatatbeh, 17, and Zahi Tawfik Hannani, 21, both were hit in the head, Arab reports said. The deaths raised to 633 the number of Palestinians killed by Israelis since the start of the Palestinian revolt in December 1987. Forty-three Israelis also have been slain, and 161 other Palestinians have been killed by fellow Arabs, most on suspicion of collaborating with Israel. In the West Bank town of Bethlehem, soldiers putting up strings of colored lights for Christmas Eve choir services were stoned by Palestinian youths wearing green head bands of the Islamic Jihad fundamentalist movement, witnesses said. The soldiers were decorating because Palestinian municipal officials have canceled Christmas festivities in solidarity with the uprising. The troops chased the stone throwers, but no arrests were reported. The army announced Thursday that it has adopted rules to punish the parents of child stone throwers in the Gaza Strip by confiscating property or sealing off rooms in houses. The spokesman said the steps were being taken because minors, those under age 12, cannot be jailed under Israeli law. ``All this is because we can't put the boy in jail,'' said the spokesman, who cannot be identified under military regulations. The new rules require parents to post bail if a child is caught throwing stones repeatedly. The spokesman said that if a family refused to pay, the army could confiscate property or seal a room of the family's house.
